text: This introductory course provides students with little or no programming experience an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems and helps them confidently write small programs to accomplish useful goals using Python 3.5【95726523693067†L154-L170】.

This subject is aimed at students with little to no programming experience. It aims to provide students with an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems and to help students feel confident writing simple programs using Python 3【973265290027091†L146-L156】.

This course is a continuation of 6.0001 and is intended for students with little or no programming experience. It teaches how computation can solve problems and helps students become confident in writing small programs using Python 3.5【442466411969269†L128-L140】.

This course introduces mathematical modeling of computational problems, covering common algorithms, algorithmic paradigms and data structures. It emphasizes the relationship between algorithms and programming and introduces basic performance measures and analysis techniques【693635301349289†L140-L150】.

This intermediate algorithms course focuses on techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, including divide‑and‑conquer, randomization, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, incremental improvement, complexity and cryptography【695750786809320†L160-L166】.

This foundation subject in modern software development covers design and development of component‑based software using C# and .NET, data structures and algorithms for modeling, analysis and visualization, problem‑solving techniques, web services and the management and maintenance of software【217962786708062†L123-L142】.

This course gives students with programming experience practical exposure to challenges unique to internet applications, including concurrency, unpredictable load, security risks, wide‑area distributed computing, reliable stateful user experiences over stateless protocols, extreme requirements and changing requirements, and multi‑modal interfaces【308677849209151†L123-L147】.

This reading and discussion subject covers issues in the engineering of software systems and software project design. Topics include the software process and lifecycle, requirements and specifications, design principles, testing, formal analysis and reviews, quality management, metrics, reuse, evolution, maintenance, team organization and the software engineering aspects of programming languages【175633647030557†L102-L116】.

This course introduces concepts and techniques relevant to the production of large software systems. Students learn a programming method based on the recognition and description of useful abstractions and study modularity, specification, data abstraction, object modeling, design patterns and testing. They complete programming projects individually and in groups【657377493828816†L135-L150】.

6.172 is a hands‑on, project‑based class introducing students to building scalable, high‑performance software systems. Topics include performance analysis, algorithmic techniques for high performance, instruction‑level optimizations, caching optimizations, parallel programming and building scalable systems【545193960175505†L147-L156】.

This course introduces fundamental principles and techniques of software development for writing software that is safe from bugs, easy to understand and ready for change. It includes problem sets and a final project and covers specifications, invariants, testing, abstract data types, design patterns for object‑oriented programming, concurrent programming and functional programming【309974996818733†L119-L124】.

The 6.005 course website lists a series of readings and problem sets covering topics such as static checking, basic Java, testing, code review, version control, specifications, designing specifications, recursion, debugging, abstract data types, interfaces, equality, regular expressions and grammars, parser generators, concurrency, thread safety, sockets and networking, queues and message‑passing, locks and synchronization, graphical user interfaces, map‑filter‑reduce and team version control【442261262257655†L9-L29】.
The quizzes page for the Performance Engineering course lists several practice quizzes with solutions, providing exam practice for students enrolled in 6.172【831509452811566†L147-L154】.

This section introduces high‑level programming languages (HLLs) which allow programmers to focus on problem solving and design without managing low‑level details. It explains that HLLs abstract away complexity and discusses cross‑platform languages like Java and C#, and criteria for choosing a language【286261373723336†L68-L96】.

This section outlines programming language constructs and sets learning objectives such as discussing and comparing high‑level language data types, demonstrating the use of variables and expressions, describing flow of control and functions, classifying well‑structured programs, introducing exception handling and summarizing file input/output【408187027897404†L68-L90】.

The chapter summary notes that functional programming is a declarative paradigm where programs are constructed by composing functions; object‑oriented programming is based on classes and objects and its degree of encapsulation, inheritance and polymorphism defines the degree of object orientation; concurrency allows multitasking; parallelism allows simultaneous execution; and scripting languages retain many compiled language features while often being interpreted【585161830811427†L128-L142】.

The summary explains that compilers translate source code to machine code while interpreters translate code line by line; compilation includes stages of code analysis, optional optimization and code generation; linkers combine separately compiled pieces; runtime systems handle features like garbage collection, exception handling and concurrency or parallelism; and code optimization improves program performance【585161830811427†L144-L165】.

The practice exercises ask learners to research data types of Java and C++ and compare them, explain differences between compilation and interpretation, compare HLLs for iPhone and Android development, list criteria for choosing among HLLs, describe the purpose of APIs, discuss indentation versus curly braces, write conditional statements and recursive functions, explore encapsulation and inheritance, and complete other programming tasks【550634119124†L86-L132】.
